thread.title: Online Lender SoFi Gets First AAA Grades on Student-Loan Bonds
thread.title_full: Online Lender SoFi Gets First AAA Grades on Student-Loan Bonds - Bloomberg Business

author: Jody Shenn
title: Online Lender SoFi Gets First AAA Grades on Student-Loan Bonds
text:
Social Finance Inc., the four-year-old online lender that’s said to be in talks to raise about $800 million in a new round of capital, is getting top ratings for the first time on securities backed by its student loans.
DBRS Ltd. is granting AAA grades to $387 million of the bonds in a $418 million offering Wednesday, according to a presale report.
While other student lenders often get top rankings on securities backed by their loans, the AAAs were a first for bonds backed by debt originating from a new breed of online finance company that also includes LendingClub Corp., On Deck Capital Inc. and CommonBond Inc. SoFi Chief Financial Officer Nino Fanlo said his firm has issued about two-thirds of the rated transactions from such lenders so far.
“SoFi continues to have a leadership role in getting transactions to the capital markets,” he said in an interview.
DBRS expects the underlying loans in SoFi’s deal to default a bit more in a “base case” scenario than those backing bonds sold last month by the lender that it ranked a level lower. Still, the ratings firm has grown more comfortable with the lender’s business, analyst Jon Riber said. Of the $2.3 billion in student loans it’s originated, only five have been charged off, with borrowers dying in most of those cases, he said.
‘Impressive’ Record “That’s a very impressive track record so far, so we took that into account,” Riber said.
Moody’s Investors Service is offering ratings on the securities receiving top grades from DBRS that are two levels lower.
The separate capital financing being sought by San Francisco-based SoFi, which focuses on refinancing government-backed student loans into private debt, may value it at about $3 billion, people with knowledge of the matter said earlier this week.
SoFi started as a so-called peer-to-peer lending company -- matching borrowers with retail investors, rather than a bank -- for Stanford University students and graduates. Riber said that he wouldn’t use the peer-to-peer label to describe the company anymore. Fanlo said he prefers “fintech” for the firm and its peers, because it’s “a financial company that uses technology to implement its strategy.”
